messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Phase Transition of the ùëò-Majority Dynamics in Biased Communication Models

Paper Abstract: Abstract Consider a graph where each of the nùëõn nodes is either in state ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} or ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B}. Herein, we analyze the synchronous kùëòk-Majority dynamics, where in each discrete-time round nodes simultaneously sample kùëòk neighbors uniformly at random with replacement and adopt the majority state among those of the nodes in the sample (breaking ties uniformly at random). Differently from previous work, we study the robustness of the kùëòk-Majority in maintaining a ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} majority, when the dynamics is subject to two forms of bias toward state ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B}. The bias models an external agent that attempts to subvert the initial majority by altering the communication between nodes, with a probability of success pùëùp in each round: in the first form of bias, the agent tries to alter the communication links by transmitting state ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B}; in the second form of bias, the agent tries to corrupt nodes directly by making them update to ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\mathcal{B}. Our main result shows a sharp phase transition in both forms of bias. By considering initial configurations in which every node has probability q‚àà(12,1]ùëû121q\in(\frac{1}{2},1] of being in state ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R}, we prove that for every k‚â•3ùëò3k\geq 3 there exists a critical value pk,q‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùëû‚ãÜp_{k,q}^{\star} such that, with high probability, the external agent is able to subvert the initial majority either in nœâ‚Äã(1)superscriptùëõùúî1n^{\omega(1)} rounds, if p<pk,q‚ãÜùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùëû‚ãÜp<p_{k,q}^{\star}, or in O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) rounds, if p>pk,q‚ãÜùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëòùëû‚ãÜp>p_{k,q}^{\star}. When k<3ùëò3k<3, instead, no phase transition phenomenon is observed and the disruption happens in O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) rounds for p>0ùëù0p>0.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A simple population protocol for fast robust approximate majority",
        "Majority dynamics and the median process: connections, convergence and some new conjectures",
        "Biased opinion dynamics: when the devil is in the details",
        "Local majority dynamics on preferential attachment graphs",
        "Global majority consensus by local majority polling on graphs of a given degree sequence",
        "Reasoning about consensus when opinions diffuse through majority dynamics",
        "Fast consensus via the unconstrained undecided state dynamics",
        "Ignore or comply?: On breaking symmetry in consensus",
        "Stabilizing consensus with many opinions",
        "Simple dynamics for plurality consensus",
        "Consensus dynamics: An overview",
        "Convergence, unanimity and disagreement in majority dynamics on unimodular graphs and random graphs",
        "Step-by-step community detection in volume-regular graphs",
        "Bounds on the voter model in dynamic networks",
        "Asynchronous majority dynamics in preferential attachment trees",
        "Minimizing message size in stochastic communication patterns: fast self-stabilizing protocols with 3 bits",
        "Coalescing random walks and voting on connected graphs",
        "The power of two choices in distributed voting",
        "Fast consensus for voting on general expander graphs",
        "A tight analysis of the parallel undecided-state dynamics with two colors",
        "Nonlinear q-voter model",
        "Brief announcement: Phase transitions of the k-majority dynamics in a biased communication model",
        "Phase transitions of the k-majority dynamics in a biased communication model",
        "Phase transition of the 2-choices dynamics on core-periphery networks",
        "Distributed community detection via metastability of the 2-choices dynamics",
        "Fast plurality consensus in regular expanders",
        "Phase transition of a non-linear opinion dynamics with noisy interactions - (extended abstract)",
        "Reaching a consensus",
        "Stabilizing consensus with the power of two choices",
        "Concentration of measure for the analysis of randomized algorithms",
        "Finite particle systems and infection models",
        "Phase transition of the 3-majority dynamics with uniform communication noise",
        "Brief announcement: Rapid asynchronous plurality consensus",
        "Breathe before speaking: efficient information dissemination despite noisy, limited and anonymous communication",
        "Reaching consensus via non-bayesian asynchronous learning in social networks",
        "Social influence and opinions",
        "Noisy rumor spreading and plurality consensus",
        "Nearly-tight analysis for 2-choice and 3-majority consensus dynamics",
        "Majority model on random regular graphs",
        "Ergodic theorems for weakly interacting infinite systems and the voter model",
        "Stochastic blockmodels: First steps",
        "Distributed probabilistic polling and applications to proportionate agreement",
        "On coalescence time in graphs: When is coalescing as fast as meeting?: Extended abstract",
        "Dynamics of majority rule in two-state interacting spin systems",
        "Best-of-three voting on dense graphs",
        "Finite Markov chains",
        "Biased majority opinion dynamics: Exploiting graph kùëòk-domination",
        "Interacting particle systems, volume 276",
        "Occam‚Äôs razor in opinion dynamics: The weighted-median influence process",
        "Information theory, inference and learning algorithms",
        "Binary opinion dynamics with biased agents and agents with different degrees of stubbornness",
        "Majority dynamics and aggregation of information in social networks",
        "Opinion exchange dynamics",
        "Network security: private communication in a public world",
        "Opinion dynamics: Models, extensions and external effects",
        "Quasi-majority functional voting on expander graphs",
        "Opinion forming in erd≈ës-r√©nyi random graph and expanders"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Phase Transition of the ùëò-Majority Dynamics in Biased Communication Models, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
